Bimetallic and trimetallic Pt-based catalysts for selective hydrogenation of p-chloronitrobenzene to p-chloroaniline Aohui Xiao Conceptualization Investigation Data curation Validation Writing – original draft a 1 Huawu Xu Conceptualization Investigation Formal analysis Validation Writing – original draft a 1 Hongjie Cui Formal analysis Resources Writing – review & editing b Zhenmin Cheng Methodology Resources Writing – review & editing a Zhiming Zhou Conceptualization Methodology Resources Writing – review & editing Project administration Supervision Funding acquisition a ⁎ a School of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai 200237, China School of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology Shanghai 200237 China School of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai 200237, China b Laboratory of Molecular Nanostructure and Nanotechnology, Institute of Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, China Laboratory of Molecular Nanostructure and Nanotechnology, Institute of Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100190 China Laboratory of Molecular Nanostructure and Nanotechnology, Institute of Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 Aohui Xiao and Huawu Xu contributed equally. The selective hydrogenation of p-chloronitrobenzene (p-CNB) is a crucial step in the preparation of p-chloroaniline (p-CAN). However, the competitive reactions of NO2 hydrogenation and C-Cl hydrogenolysis make it challenging to inhibit the undesired dechlorination side reaction during this process. Herein, we developed a series of bimetallic PtM/γ-Al2O3 (M = Co, Cu, Ni, Fe, Zn, Ga, and Sn) and trimetallic PtCuCox/γ-Al2O3 catalysts to enhance the selectivity of p-CAN and suppress the formation of aniline (AN). Among the bimetallic catalysts, PtCo/γ-Al2O3 showed the highest hydrogenation activity due to its high electron-rich degree of Pt. Conversely, PtCu/γ-Al2O3 displayed the highest p-CAN selectivity and the lowest AN selectivity, primarily owing to the presence of electron-deficient Pt. Remarkably, the trimetallic PtCuCo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited superior hydrogenation performance, achieving 97.3 % p-CAN selectivity and 0.4 % AN selectivity at complete conversion of p-CNB, while maintaining good stability over five cycles. This enhancement was attributed to the synergistic effect among Pt, Cu and Co. To further investigate the effect of support, we prepared bimetallic PtM3 (M = Co, Cu, Ni and Zn) catalysts supported on reducible CeO2. Interestingly, the use of CeO2 as a support facilitated the condensation path from p-CNB to p-CAN via azobenzene compounds, distinct from the direct path observed with γ-Al2O3 support. Furthermore, the AN selectivity on all PtM3/CeO2 was less than 1 %, indicating effective inhibition of dechlorination reactions. This study highlights the importance of a multi-metal synergistic strategy and the effect of the support to achieve superior performance in chloronitrobenzene hydrogenation. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Selective hydrogenation P-chloronitrobenzene Pt-based catalyst Electronic effect Synergistic effect Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Chloroanilines as important organic intermediates are widely used in dyes, pesticides, pharmaceuticals and other fine chemicals [1]. Chloroanilines can be synthesized from chloro-nitrobenzenes using methods such as chemical reduction (Béchamp process) [2], electrochemical reduction [3,4], and catalytic reduction [4]. With a growing emphasis on green chemistry, catalytic hydrogenation has emerged as a more desirable approach due to its ability to produce high-quality while minimizing pollution. The catalytic hydrogenation process of chloronitrobenzenes is complex and involves parallel and sequential reactions. The selective hydrogenation of chloronitrobenzenes follows a reaction network that was initially proposed by Haber [5], which can be divided into two main paths: the direct path and the condensation path (Fig. S1). In the direct path, chloronitrobenzene is first reduced to chloronitrosobenzene, which further converts to chlorophenylhydroxylamine, and finally, to chloroaniline. In contrast, the condensation path leads to the formation of azobenzene intermediates. Noteworthy is that a significant challenge arises from the occurrence of the hydrodechlorination side reaction, particularly during the conversion of chloroaniline. This side reaction might be attributed to the electron-donating of the amino group, which increases the electron density around the carbon-chlorine (C-Cl) bond. Consequently, inhibiting the dechlorination side reaction becomes a key challenge in improving the selectivity of chloroaniline. Both noble metal (such as Pt [6,7], Pd [8,9], Au [10] and Ru [11]) and non-noble metal (such as Ni [12,13], Co [14], Fe [15] and Cu [16]) catalysts have been commonly used for the selective hydrogenation of chloronitrobenzenes. Among these catalysts, Pt-based catalysts are known for their high activity under mild conditions. However, they still suffer from the issue of hydrodechlorination side reactions. To address this challenge, the introduction of a second metal has been explored to modulate the geometric and electronic effects of the active sites, thereby improving the hydrogenation performance [17]. For instance, Iihama et al. [18] prepared a series of Pt-based bimetallic catalysts supported on silica (PtM/SiO2) and found that intermetallic PtZn/SiO2 exhibited excellent hydrogenation performance under 1 atm H2 and 40 °C. This enhancement was attributed to the electron-rich Pt, which not only promoted the hydrogenation of halonitrobenzene but also inhibited the dechlorination side reaction. Li et al. [19] investigated two types of Pt-Cu/C catalysts with different reduction sequences and observed a significant difference in hydrogenation activity while maintaining high selectivity for both catalysts. More recently, Zhu et al. [20] demonstrated that PtNiCo/C trimetallic catalyst outperformed other monometallic or bimetallic catalysts in nitrobenzene hydrogenation. This superior performance was ascribed to the synergistic effect between Pt and (Ni,Co)(OH)2. Additionally, Lu et al. [21] developed a PtPdCoCuNi/SiO2 high-entropy alloy catalyst for nitrobenzene hydrogenation. This catalyst showed improved aniline yield, which was attributed to the geometric and electronic effects resulting from alloying the transition metals. However, it is important to note that achieving high selectivity often comes at the expense of catalytic activity [22]. Therefore, it is still challenging to develop effective catalysts that possess both high activity and selectivity. The choice of support material in supported metal catalysts plays a significant role in determining catalyst structures and hydrogenation performance. Supports can generally be categorized into two types: reducible supports (such as CeO2, TiO2, Fe2O3, etc.) and nonreducible supports (such as Al2O3, SiO2, MgO, etc.). The presence of reducible supports can facilitate strong interactions between the metal and support, thereby influencing the geometric and electronic effects of the active sites and leading to enhanced catalytic performance. For example, Han et al. [23] studied the effect of different supports on the hydrogenation performance of chloronitrobenzene and found that Pt/TiO2 exhibited superior performance due to strong metal-support interactions. Wang et al. [24] discovered that the electronic effect dominated the performance of chloronitrobenzene hydrogenation when the metal particle sizes were similar. This observation explained the higher activity and selectivity of chloroaniline achieved on reducible supports. Moreover, the support material itself can adsorb reactants and intermediates, thus influencing the reaction pathway [25]. In addition to the more commonly used reducible supports, MgF2, which is a rather uncommon support material, has shown potential in the selective hydrogenation of chloronitrobenzenes [26–29]. For instance, a highly active and selective Pt/MgF2 catalyst was developed for the hydrogenation of o-chloronitrobenzene (o-CNB) to o-chloroaniline [26]. In this case, the coordinatively unsaturated magnesium cations serve as the centers for o-CNB adsorption, while the interaction between Pt and fluoride ions leads to the formation of electron-deficient Pt. In this study, a series of PtM/γ-Al2O3 bimetallic catalysts were prepared to investigate the effect of the second metal species on catalyst properties and the catalytic performance in the selective hydrogenation of p-chloronitrobenzene (p-CNB). Among the bimetallic catalysts tested, PtCo/γ-Al2O3 exhibited the highest hydrogenation activity, while PtCu/γ-Al2O3 showed the highest selectivity towards p-chloroaniline (p-CAN) and the lowest selectivity towards aniline (AN). This finding indicates the presence of a trade-off relationship between catalytic activity and selectivity. Subsequently, a PtCuCo/γ-Al2O3 trimetallic catalyst was synthesized, and it displayed higher hydrogenation activity and p-CAN selectivity compared to PtCu/γ-Al2O3. This enhancement in performance can be attributed to the synergistic effect among Pt, Cu, and Co in the trimetallic catalyst. Furthermore, the reusability of the optimal catalyst was evaluated, and the influence of reaction temperature and pressure on the catalytic performance were studied. Finally, a reducible support material, CeO2, was chosen to support Pt and the second metals. The effect of the second metal on the structure-performance relationship of PtM3/CeO2 was also investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Chloroplatinic acid hexahydrate (H2PtCl6·6 H2O, 99.9 %), cobaltous nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6 H2O, 99 %), cupric nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O, > 99 %), ferric nitrate nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O, 98 %), gallium nitrate (Ga(NO3)2, ≥ 99 %), stannic chloride pentahydrate (SnCl4·5 H2O, > 98 %), p-chloronitrobenzene (C6H4ClNO2, 99 %), n-dodecane (C12H26, 99 %), and absolute ethanol (C2H5OH, ≥ 99.7 %) were purchased from Shanghai Titan Scientific Co., Ltd. Nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O, ≥ 98 %), zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6 H2O, ≥ 99 %), ceric ammonium nitrate (Ce(NH4)2(NO3)6, ≥ 99 %), and citric acid (C6H8O7, ≥ 99.5 %) were supplied by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. γ-Al2O3 was obtained from Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd. All chemicals were used without further treatment. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Preparation of PtMxNy/γ-Al2O3 Pt-based mono-, bi-, and tri-metallic catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3 were prepared by impregnation method. A typical preparation of PtCo/γ-Al2O3 was as follows: first, a certain amount of H2PtCl6, Co(NO3)2·6 H2O and γ-Al2O3 were added to 30 mL of deionized water, and stirred at room temperature for 10 h; then, the solvent was removed by using a rotary evaporator at 70 °C, and the resulting solid was further dried in an oven at 120 °C for 12 h; next, the dried solid was ground into powder and calcined in a muffle furnace at 450 °C for 3 h, with a heating rate of 2 °C/min; finally, the powder was reduced by a tube furnace in 10% H2/N2 (50 mL/min) at 500 °C for 2 h, with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The other catalysts (PtMx/γ-Al2O3 and PtCuMx/γ-Al2O3, where x represents the nominal molar ratio of M/Pt, and x is omitted when x = 1) were prepared using a similar procedure. In all the Pt-based catalysts, the nominal loading of Pt was maintained at 1.0 wt%. 2.2.2 Preparation of PtM3/CeO2 Pt-based mono- and bi-metallic catalysts supported on CeO2 were prepared using a one-pot sol-gel method. Taking PtNi3/CeO2 as an example, the preparation procedure was as follows: first, a certain amount of H2PtCl6, Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O, Ce(NH4)2(NO3)6 and citric acid were added to 50 mL deionized water, and the mixed solution was vigorously stirred at 80 °C for 6 h; then, the resulting sol was transferred to an oven and dried at 120 °C for 12 h to form a gel; next, the gel was ground into power and calcined at 550 °C for 4 h in a muffle furnace with a heating rate of 2 °C/min; finally, the powder was reduced in 10 % H2/N2 (50 mL/min) at 500 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. For the preparation of other bimetallic catalysts (PtM3/CeO2, where M = Co, Cu, and Zn), only the precursor of the second metal was altered. In these cases, the nominal loading of Pt was kept at 1 wt%, and the nominal molar ratio of M/Pt was set to 3/1. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were conducted on a Micromeritics AutoChem 2920 instrument. Around 100 mg of catalyst was heated from room temperature to 800 °C at 10 °C/min under a flow of 10 % H2/N2 (50 mL/min). The H2 consumption was monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). CO-pulse chemisorption (Micromeritics AutoChem 2920) was performed to determine the number of active sites. The catalyst was first reduced at 500 °C for 1 h in 10 % H2/N2, followed by switching to He at 530 °C for 30 min to remove surface-adsorbed H2. After cooling down to 30 °C, CO pulses were injected until the CO peak area remained constant. The uptake of CO was recorded by TCD. The actual metal loading in the catalyst was determined by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Agilent 725-ES). The textural property of the catalysts was characterized by N2 adsorption–desorption at − 196 °C using a Micrometrics ASAP 2010 instrument. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were acquired on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer using Cu/Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å) over a 2θ range of 10–80° with a step size of 0.02°. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images of the catalysts were obtained using a JEOL JEM-2100 microscope. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscope (HAADF-STEM) was performed on a ThermoFisher Talos F200X instrument. The distribution and average size of metal nanoparticles were determined by analyzing at least 100 particles. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out using a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi instrument with an Al Kα radiation source (hν = 1486.6 eV, 40 eV pass energy). The C 1 s peak (284.8 eV) was used for charge calibration. 2.4 Evaluation of catalysts The selective hydrogenation of p-CNB was performed in a 300 mL semi-batch tank reactor (Parr 5100) equipped with mechanical stirring. In a typical procedure, 0.2 g of catalyst was added into the reactor, which contained 5 g of p-CNB, 5 g of n-dodecane (internal standard), and 90 g of ethanol (solvent). The mixture was heated to 60 °C under a N2 atmosphere. The N2 was then replaced by purging the reactor with H2 for five times. The reaction was initiated at 60 °C and 0.5 MPa under a H2 atmosphere with stirring at 1000 rpm. At certain time intervals, approximately 1 mL of the reaction solution was withdrawn for analysis. The concentration of the product was determined using a gas chromatograph equipped with a capillary column (PEG-20 M, 30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.50 µm) and a flame ionization detector. The conversion of p-CNB, the selectivity of p-CAN, and the selectivity of AN are calculated as follows: (1) Conversion = Moles of p − CNB initially − Moles of p − CNB at time t Moles of p − CNB initially × 100 % (2) p − CAN selectivity = Moles of p − CAN produced at time t Moles of p − CNB initially − Moles of p − CNB at time t × 100 % (3) AN selectivity = Moles of AN produced at time t Moles of p − CNB initially − Moles of p − CNB at time t × 100 % The catalytic activity can be characterized by the initial reaction rate (r), which is defined as the number of moles of p-CNB consumed per second per gram of catalyst during the initial period. r can be calculated by: (4) r = F α tm where F is the molar amount of p-CNB in the feedstock, moles; α is the conversion of p-CNB (< 30 %); t is the reaction time required to reach α conversion, s; m is the mass of catalyst, g. The carbon balance (C-balance) is used to indicate the quantity of intermediate produced, and it is calculated by: (5) C − balance = ( ∑ Moles of p − CNB , p − CAN and A N ) at time t Moles of p − CNB initially × 100 % Clearly, the closer the C-balance value approaches 100 %, the lower the amount of intermediate is produced. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Bimetallic PtM/γ-Al2O3 catalysts Fig. 1a shows the H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts. There are two reduction peaks in Pt/γ-Al2O3: the first peak at 235 °C is attributed to the reduction of platinum oxide species (PtOx) that interact weakly with the support; the second peak at 350 °C is ascribed to the reduction of platinum chloride oxide species (PtOxCly) which has a strong interaction with the support [30]. Similarly, the bimetallic catalysts also display two reduction peaks. The second reduction peak, observed at higher temperatures with increased peak areas for the Co-, Cu-, Fe-, and Zn-introduced catalysts, corresponds to the reduction of CoO [31], CuO [32], FeOx [33], and ZnO [34] in addition to PtOxCly reduction. In the case of PtNi/γ-Al2O3, the reduction peaks are associated with the reduction of PtOx and NiOx [35]. Likewise, in PtGa/γ-Al2O3, the two reduction peaks are attributed to the reduction of PtOx and highly dispersed Ga species [36]; PtSn/γ-Al2O3 exhibits a broad peak at 150–450 °C, corresponding to the co-reduction of PtOx and SnO2 [37]. Hence, all the catalysts were activated at 500 °C prior to the hydrogenation reaction, ensuring the reduction of active metals. Table S1 provides the actual loadings of Pt and M in PtM/γ-Al2O3 as measured by ICP-OES, and the actual M/Pt ratio is close to the nominal value (i.e., 1). The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of PtM/γ-Al2O3 are shown in Fig. S2. According to the IUPAC classification [38], all catalysts exhibit type Ⅳ isotherms with H3-type hysteresis loops, indicating the presence of mesoporous structure. Additionally, they all display a unimodal pore size distribution in the range of 5–10 nm. The specific surface area, pore volume and average pore size are further determined (Table S2), and they remain nearly unchanged, which could be attributed to the low metal loading. Fig. 1b shows the XRD patterns of γ-Al2O3 support and PtM/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. γ-Al2O3 exhibits broad peaks with low intensity at 2θ = 37.6, 39.5, 45.9 and 67.0° (PDF #10-0425), indicating a relatively low crystallinity. For Pt/γ-Al2O3 and PtM/γ-Al2O3, only the characteristic peak of γ-Al2O3 is observed. The absence of typical characteristic peaks of Pt and the second metal may be due to the low metal loading and the small metal particle size. The HRTEM and EDS mapping images of PtM/γ-Al2O3 are shown in Fig. 2. It can be seen that γ-Al2O3 exhibits a thin fibrous shape. However, no significant metal particles or lattice fringes are detected, which may be attributed to the small metal particle size. To further investigate the metallic phases and metal dispersion in the catalysts, HAADF-STEM analysis was conducted. Fig. S3 displays the results, revealing highly dispersed Pt particles with an average size of 1.0 nm in Pt/γ-Al2O3. This observation is consistent with the absence of metal diffraction peaks in the XRD analysis. In addition, the EDS mapping images demonstrate the well dispersion of Pt and the second metal on the surface of γ-Al2O3, along with uniform contact of Pt-M particles. It should be noted that PtCu/γ-Al2O3 appears to contain a relatively larger amount of Cu particles compared to Pt, primarily due to the utilization of a copper grid for the HRTEM analysis. To investigate the electronic structure of the active metal Pt, the XPS spectra of PtM/γ-Al2O3 are presented in Fig. 3. Since the Pt 4 f signal is overlapped by a strong Al 2p peak, the Pt 4d spectrum is chosen for analyzed instead of Pt 4 f [39]. In the Pt 4d5/2 region of Pt/γ-Al2O3, the two peaks deconvoluted at 314.7 and 316.5 eV are assigned to Pt0 and Pt2+ species, respectively [39]. For the bimetallic catalysts PtM/γ-Al2O3, the difference in electronegativity between Pt and the second metal could influence the electron cloud density of Pt. Specifically, the introduction of Co, Ni, Fe, Zn, Ga, and Sn shifts the Pt0 4d5/2 peak towards a lower binding energy. This shift indicates the electron transfer from the second metal (M) to Pt, resulting in an electron-rich Pt [18,40–42]. Conversely, in the case of PtCu/γ-Al2O3, the electron transfer from Pt to Cu leads to an electron-poor state for Pt [18]. The XPS results clearly demonstrate that the introduction of the second metal alters the electronic structure of Pt within the catalyst. The concentration profiles of p-CNB, p-CAN and AN during the p-CNB hydrogenation over PtM/γ-Al2O3 are shown in Fig. S4. In general, before reaching 80 % conversion of p-CNB, all catalysts exhibit an approximately linear change in the concentration profiles. However, as the p-CNB concentration further decreases, the reaction rate diminishes. Fig. S4 also presents the changes in C-balance data during reaction. Pt/γ-Al2O3 has a high C-balance value of > 95 % throughout the reaction process, indicating that only a small amount of intermediates is generated. This suggests that the direct path from p-CNB to p-CAN via phenylhydroxylamine intermediates (Fig. S1) is more likely to occur when γ-Al2O3 is used as the support. Upon introducing the second metal, the C-balance data in PtCu/γ-Al2O3 remain above 95 %, while the C-balance data for other PtM/γ-Al2O3 are lower than 95 %. The variation in C-balance data primarily stems from the different electronic structure of Pt in PtM/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. For PtM/γ-Al2O3 (M = Co, Ni, Fe, Zn, Ga and Sn) catalysts, the electron-rich state of Pt hinders the adsorption of intermediates, thereby impeding further hydrogenation and leading to their accumulation [43]. Table 1 lists the hydrogenation activity calculated from the concentration profiles. Among all the catalysts, Pt/γ-Al2O3 achieves complete conversion of p-CNB in 25 min, while PtCo/γ-Al2O3 exhibits the shortest conversion time of 11 min. On the other hand, PtCu/γ-Al2O3 requires the longest time for complete conversion, which is 180 min. Additionally, it is found that the initial rates of PtM/γ-Al2O3 are generally correlated positively with the CO uptake data (Table S2), which is reasonable as the CO uptake reflects the number of active sites available for the reactions. Furthermore, the electronic effect of the second metal on Pt affects the adsorption of the reactants. The electron-rich Pt enhances the adsorption of electron-deficient NO2 group [44], thereby promoting the hydrogenation of p-CNB, as illustrated in Fig. 4a. XPS analysis reveals that PtCo/γ-Al2O3 has the highest electron-rich degree for Pt, which contributes to its superior hydrogenation activity. The selectivity results are also presented in Table 1. Compared with the p-CAN selectivity of Pt/γ-Al2O3 (89.6 %), the bimetallic catalysts incorporating Cu, Ni and Zn exhibit higher p-CAN selectivity, with PtCu/γ-Al2O3 showing the highest selectivity of 95.4 %. Conversely, the p-CAN selectivity decreases when Co, Fe, Ga and Sn are introduced as the second metal. The AN selectivity of aniline reflects the occurrence of hydrodechlorination as a side reaction. The AN selectivity is 7.0 % over Pt/γ-Al2O3, which decreases after the introduction of the second metal (except for PtGa/γ-Al2O3). Among them, only 0.1 % of AN selectivity is observed on PtCu/γ-Al2O3, indicating the nearly complete suppression of the dechlorination side reaction. This phenomenon can be attributed to the more positive charge of Pt in PtCu/γ-Al2O3. The electron-deficient Pt sites reduce the electron feedback during the adsorption of p-CAN, thus weakening the reactivity of the C-Cl bond [45,46]. Moreover, the repulsion interaction between electron-rich Cu (due to electron transfer from Pt to Cu) and -Cl group (the negative part of p-CNB) somewhat suppresses the cleavage of C-Cl bond [8]. Both effects inhibit the hydrodechlorination reaction (Fig. 4b). It is known that the content of the second metal plays a crucial role in determining the catalyst performance, as it can produce different geometric and electronic effects when combined with the active metal. To explore the effect of M/Pt molar ratios, Co, Cu and Ni are chosen based on the above results. The H2-TPR profiles of PtMx/γ-Al2O3 (M = Co, Cu and Ni; x = 0.3–10) are shown in Fig. S5. As the M/Pt molar ratio increases, the interaction between Pt and the second metal becomes more evident. Fig. S6 presents the hydrogenation performance of p-CNB over PtMx/γ-Al2O3. The results indicate that Co/γ-Al2O3, Cu/γ-Al2O3, and Ni/γ-Al2O3 exhibit no activity for p-CNB hydrogenation, implying that Pt is the active metal in this process. With an increase in the M/Pt molar ratio, the hydrogenation activity of the catalysts gradually decreases, which could be attributed to the coverage of some Pt active sites by the second metal. Notably, for PtCu3/γ-Al2O3, only 22 % of p-CNB is converted within 360 min, indicating a low hydrogenation activity. As regards the selectivity obtained at > 99 % conversion of p-CNB, the p-CAN selectivity generally increases with the M/Pt molar ratio, while the AN selectivity decreases. Specifically, within their respective series, PtCo10/γ-Al2O3 and PtNi10/γ-Al2O3 show the highest p-CAN selectivity and the lowest AN selectivity (94.8 % p-CAN and 2.2 % AN for PtCo10/γ-Al2O3, and 93.4 % p-CAN and 2.1 % AN for PtNi10/γ-Al2O3). However, when it comes to PtCux/γ-Al2O3, only the catalysts with x ≤ 1 are tested until complete conversion of p-CNB, owing to the considerably low activity of the catalysts with x > 1. Among PtCux/γ-Al2O3 (x = 0.3, 0.5, 0.8, and 1.0), PtCu/γ-Al2O3 has the highest P-CAN selectivity (95.4 %) and the lowest AN selectivity (0.1 %). The above results demonstrate that increasing the M/Pt molar ratio in PtCox/γ-Al2O3 and PtNix/γ-Al2O3 catalysts can somewhat improve the p-CAN selectivity and suppress the dechlorination side reaction. However, these enhancements in selectivity are still inferior to the performance of PtCu/γ-Al2O3. Conversely, PtCu/γ-Al2O3 exhibits significantly lower activity compared to PtCo10/γ-Al2O3 and PtNi10/γ-Al2O3. Therefore, modifying the M/Pt molar ratio in bimetallic PtMx/γ-Al2O3 catalysts appears not to be a promising strategy for overcoming the trade-off between activity and selectivity in p-CNB hydrogenation. 3.2 Trimetallic PtCuMx/γ-Al2O3 catalysts Considering the remarkable ability of PtCu/γ-Al2O3 to inhibit the dechlorination side reaction, the introduction of a third metal into PtCu/γ-Al2O3 is pursued to enhance the hydrogenation activity of the catalyst while concurrently suppressing the dechlorination reaction. Co, Ni, and Zn are chosen as potential third metals for the preparation of PtCuM/γ-Al2O3 due to their capability to promote the hydrogenation activity among bimetallic catalysts (Table 1 and Fig. S4). The evaluation results of the selective hydrogenation of p-CNB on PtCuM/γ-Al2O3 (M = Co, Ni, and Zn) are summarized in Table 1. Introducing Co and Ni into the catalyst formulation leads to higher activity, with initial reaction rates of 59.74 and 59.12 μmol/(gcat·s), respectively. These rates are about three times that of PtCu/γ-Al2O3 (19.06 μmol/(gcat·s)); moreover, the reaction time required for complete conversion of p-CNB is greatly reduced from 180 min to 100–120 min. PtCuZn/γ-Al2O3 also shows a higher initial rate (31.43 μmol/(gcat·s)) than that of PtCu/γ-Al2O3, but the reaction time for complete conversion of p-CNB is prolonged to 210 min. As for selectivity, PtCuCo/γ-Al2O3 shows the highest p-CAN selectivity (97.3 %) and the lowest AN selectivity (0.4 %) among PtCuM/γ-Al2O3 (M = Co, Ni, and Zn). Compared to PtCu/γ-Al2O3, PtCuCo/γ-Al2O3 not only demonstrates enhanced hydrogenation activity, but also achieves improved p-CAN selectivity while maintaining comparable AN selectivity. These findings motivate further exploration of the impact of Co/Pt molar ratio in PtCuCox/γ-Al2O3 on the hydrogenation performance. For trimetallic PtCuCox/γ-Al2O3 (x = 0.3, 1, and 3), the actual Cu/Pt and Co/Pt molar ratios are close to the nominal counterparts (Table S1). The H2-TPR profiles of PtCuCox/γ-Al2O3 (Fig. S7) resemble those of bimetallic catalysts, indicating the reduction of PtOx, CuO and CoO species. In addition, Fig. S8 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves of PtCuCox/γ-Al2O3. All the catalysts display type Ⅳ isotherms with H3-type hysteresis loops, indicative of a mesoporous structure [38]. Further comparison of specific surface area and pore volume (Table S2) reveals that both parameters decrease as the Co content increases, owing to the occupation of more pores by the Co species. Similar to Pt/γ-Al2O3 and other bimetallic catalysts, PtCuCox/γ-Al2O3 exhibits diffraction peaks solely ascribed to γ-Al2O3 ( Fig. 5a). In addition, the HAADF-STEM images (Fig. 5b) and EDS mapping images (Fig. 5c) of PtCuCo/γ-Al2O3 clearly demonstrate the high dispersion of Pt, Cu, and Co on the γ-Al2O3 support. The Pt 4d, Cu 2p, and Co 2p XPS spectra of PtCuCox/γ-Al2O3 are presented in Fig. 5d, which reveals the electronic interaction among the metals. The Pt0 4d5/2 peak is located at 314.6 eV for PtCuCo0.3/γ-Al2O3 and is shifted to 314.2 eV for PtCuCo3/γ-Al2O3, indicating that the introduction of Co leads to an electron-rich state for Pt. The Cu0/Cu+ 2p3/2 peak shows a slight shift from 932.9 eV to 932.8 eV (Cu0 and Cu+ are not distinguished because their binding energies are very close [47]). Regarding the Co 2p XPS spectra, PtCuCo0.3/γ-Al2O3 exhibits a weak signal due to the low Co content. The peak at 781.4 eV corresponds to Co2+, which is shifted to higher binding energy with increasing the Co/Pt ratio, suggesting the electron transfer from Co to other metals [48]. The above analysis indicates the presence of interactions among Pt, Cu and Co. As the Co/Pt molar ratios increases, the electron transfer from Co to Pt and Cu occurs, which leads to a decrease in the electron cloud density of Co and an increase in Pt and Cu. Fig. 6 displays the performance of p-CNB hydrogenation over PtCuCox/γ-Al2O3 with varying Co/Pt molar ratios, while Table 1 presents the corresponding data on activity and selectivity. Clearly, the introduction of Co (Co/Pt molar ratio = 0.3–3) enhances the apparent activity of p-CNB hydrogenation compared to PtCu/γ-Al2O3. The initial reaction rate is approximately 2–3 times that of PtCu/γ-Al2O3, and the reaction time required for complete conversion of p-CNB is shortened to 100–160 min. This increased activity of the trimetallic PtCuCox catalysts is primarily attributed to the synergistic effect among Pt, Cu and Co. Specifically, the electronic transfer from Co to Pt and Cu results in electron-rich Pt and Cu, as depicted in Fig. 4c. Among all PtCuCox/γ-Al2O3, PtCuCo/γ-Al2O3 exhibits the highest hydrogenation activity, which is in line with its highest CO uptake among all the tested PtCuCox/γ-Al2O3 (Table S2). As for the selectivity, all PtCuCox/γ-Al2O3 (x = 0.3–3) catalysts exhibit a p-CAN selectivity higher than 96 % and an AN selectivity of no more than 0.6 %, indicating that the dechlorination side reaction is effectively suppressed (although not as effectively as with PtCu/γ-Al2O3). In addition, the C-balance data in PtCuCox/γ-Al2O3 are larger than 95 % during the entire reaction process, further confirming the high selectivity towards p-CAN. The electron-rich Cu derived from the synergistic interaction among Pt, Cu and Co contributes to the inhibition of the hydrodechlorination reaction. To assess the reusability of the optimized catalyst PtCuCo/γ-Al2O3, five consecutive reaction cycles were performed, each lasting 100 min. After each reaction, the catalyst was separated from the liquid by centrifugation and washed with ethanol for the next cycle. The results are presented in Fig. 7. The conversion of p-CNB slightly decreases from 99.7 % to 94.7 %, but the p-CAN selectivity remains almost unchanged (averaged at 97.7 %). The decrease in p-CNB conversion is mostly ascribed to the loss of catalyst during the recycling process. Worthy of mention is that the AN selectivity is decreased from 0.4 % to 0.1 % after 5 cycles, which could be attributed to the coverage of some dechlorination active sites during cyclic operation, thus inhibiting the hydrodechlorination side reaction of p-CAN. A similar phenomenon was also observed by Wang et al. [49], who found that the AN selectivity decreased with decreasing the Pt/p-CNB mass ratio. They employed the infrared spectroscopy of adsorbed CO to show that the in-situ generated Cl species could poison the low-coordinated dechlorination active sites, thereby increasing the steric hindrance of surface Pt and inhibiting the dechlorination reaction. The HRTEM and EDS mapping images of the 5-cycle used catalyst are shown in Fig. S9, indicating that the metals still maintain good dispersion. Moreover, the metal loadings of the used catalyst were measured by ICP-OES, and the results show that the loadings of Pt, Cu and Co are 0.87, 0.33 and 0.27 wt% respectively. These values are very close to their counterparts in the fresh catalyst, which are 0.91, 0.33 and 0.26 wt%, respectively. Therefore, it can be concluded that PtCuCo/γ-Al2O3 exhibits good stability in p-CNB hydrogenation. Fig. 8 presents the effects of reaction temperature and pressure on the hydrogenation performance over PtCuCo/γ-Al2O3. With increasing temperature or pressure, the rate of p-CNB hydrogenation gradually accelerates. For example, the complete conversion of p-CNB takes around 60 min at 80 °C while it requires 210 min at 40 °C. Similarly, the complete conversion time of p-CNB is shorted from 180 min at 0.3 MPa to 70 min at 0.9 MPa. Regarding the p-CAN selectivity, it gradually increases with temperature or pressure, which is associated with the further conversion of the intermediates [45,50]. However, temperature and pressure have different effects on the AN selectivity. The AN selectivity increases gradually with temperature, indicating higher temperature could promote the dechlorination side reaction. In contrast, the influence of pressure on dechlorination reaction is comparatively slight [51], with the AN selectivity being ≤ 0.6 % at complete conversion of p-CNB. 3.3 Bimetallic PtM3/CeO2 catalysts The above trimetallic catalyst demonstrates outstanding performance in the selective hydrogenation of p-CNB, utilizing a typical nonreducible support (γ-Al2O3). However, for supported metal catalysts, loading metals on reducible supports is generally considered more desirable for the selective hydrogenation of chloronitrobenzenes [24]. To explore this further, we also investigate the impact of introducing a second metal with CeO2 as the support on the hydrogenation performance. Fig. 9 shows the H2-TPR profiles of the CeO2 support and PtM3/CeO2 (M = Co, Cu, Ni, and Zn) catalysts. For CeO2, two reduction peaks are observed at 300–500 °C and > 600 °C, attributed to the reduction of surface and bulk CeO2, respectively [52]. After the incorporation of Pt, a new reduction peak centered at 150 °C appears, indicating the reduction of PtOx [52]. For the bimetallic PtM3/CeO2, the reduction peak at < 200 °C is much larger than that of Pt/CeO2, implying the reduction of not only PtOx but also the second metal oxide. The ICP-OES results of PtM3/CeO2 are listed in Table S1, and the actual M/Pt molar ratio is close to the nominal value (i.e., 3). Fig. S10a shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of PtM3/CeO2, showing type Ⅳ isotherms with H3-type hysteresis loops, indicating a mesoporous structure for all samples [38]. The pore size distribution curves (Fig. S10b) exhibit a distinct mesopore at 3–4 nm. Further comparison of the specific surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter reveals no significant difference in the textural properties between the CeO2 support and PtM3/CeO2 catalysts (Table S2). In addition, except for the characteristic peaks indexed to the cubic CeO2 phase, Pt and the second metal are not identified in the XRD patterns of PtM3/CeO2 (Fig. S11), which is also ascribed to the low metal loading and the small metal particle size. Indeed, in the HRTEM images ( Fig. 10), only the lattice fringes of CeO2 are clearly observed, with spacings of 0.31, 0.27, and 0.19 nm, corresponding to the (111), (200), and (220) facets of CeO2, respectively [53]. However, the presence of Pt and the second metal is evidenced by EDS mapping images (Fig. 10), indicating their uniform distribution and close contact within the structure. Fig. 11 shows the XPS spectra of Pt 4 f, Ce 3d and O 1 s, while the corresponding relative contents of Pt0, Ce3+, and defective oxygen are provided in Table S3. In the Pt 4 f XPS spectra of Pt/CeO2 (Fig. 11a), the binding energies at 71.4 and 74.9 eV refer to Pt0 4 f7/2 and 4 f5/2, respectively, while peaks at 72.8 and 76.1 eV correspond to Pt2+ 4 f7/2 and 4 f5/2, respectively [54,55]. After introducing the second metal, the peaks of Pt0 shift to higher binding energies, indicating an electron transfer from Pt to M and resulting in a more electron-deficient state for Pt. It should be noted that the peaks located at 74.9 and 77.7 eV in PtCu3/CeO2 are attributed to Cu 3p3/2 and 3p1/2, respectively [56,57]. It can be seen from Table S3 that Pt/CeO2 has the lowest Pt0 content of 11.0 %, whereas PtZn3/CeO2 exhibits the highest content of 74.9 %. The Ce 3d XPS spectra (Fig. 11b) can been deconvoluted into two regions at 880–900 eV and 900–920 eV, corresponding to the Ce 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 peaks, respectively. Specifically, the binding energies at 882, 889 and 898 eV are assigned to Ce4+ 3d5/2, and 885 eV belongs to Ce3+ 3d5/2; furthermore, the binding energies at 901, 908 and 917 eV are assigned to Ce4+ 3d3/2, and 903 eV belongs to Ce3+ 3d3/2 [58]. It is known that oxygen defects are usually generated along with Ce3+ formation [59]. The O 1 s XPS spectra (Fig. 11c) display two peaks located at 529.6 and 531.7 eV, corresponding to lattice oxygen and defective oxygen, respectively. The defective oxygen species mainly include O2- and O-, respectively [54,60]. In Table S3, it is evident that Pt/CeO2 has the highest Ce3+ content and oxygen vacancy concentration, but PtCu3/CeO2 shows the lowest. The concentration profiles of different species and C-balance data during p-CNB hydrogenation over PtM3/CeO2 are depicted in Fig. S12. Different from Pt/γ-Al2O3, where the C-balance data throughout the hydrogenation process consistently remain above 95 % (Fig. S4), Pt/CeO2 undergoes a drastic drop in C-balance (80 % C-balance at 42.5 % conversion of p-CNB) during the initial period (0–10 min), followed by an increase to 90 % C-balance at complete conversion of p-CNB (40 min). Apparently, more intermediates are formed during the initial hydrogenation of p-CNB on Pt/CeO2 compared to Pt/γ-Al2O3. A similar phenomenon is also observed for bimetallic PtM3/CeO2. This finding indicates that, unlike the direct path from p-CNB to p-CAN via phenylhydroxylamine intermediates when γ-Al2O3 is employed as the support, the condensation path from p-CNB to p-CAN via azobenzene compounds (Fig. S1) is promoted when CeO2 is used as the support [61]. It is evident that the difference in the reaction pathway originates from the support. For PtM3/CeO2 that is reduced at 500 °C, the presence of Ce3+ and oxygen vacancy sites in the CeO2 support can adsorb the NO2 group, thereby influencing the reaction process [62]. Among all PtM3/CeO2 catalysts, PtCu3/CeO2 has almost no activity for p-CNB hydrogenation, yielding only 8.8 % conversion of p-CNB after 250 min of reaction. The hydrogenation performance of PtM3/CeO2 in p-CNB hydrogenation is summarized in Table 2 (PtCu3/CeO2 is excluded owing to its remarkably low activity). As regards the apparent activity, Pt/CeO2 achieves 99.7 % conversion of p-CNB in 40 min, whereas the activity is significantly enhanced in PtCo3/CeO2, achieving 99.8 % conversion in just 25 min. The observed variation in apparent activity is likely associated with the composition of Pt0, Ce3+ and oxygen vacancy on the catalyst surface. Pt0 sites are known to facilitate the dissociation of H2 [55], while Ce3+ and oxygen vacancy sites have the capacity to adsorb the NO2 group [62]. The XPS analysis (Table S3) reveals that PtCo3/CeO2 possesses an optimal combination of Pt0, Ce3+ and oxygen vacancy sites, which contributes to its superior apparent activity in p-CNB hydrogenation compared to other PtM3/CeO2 catalysts. As for the selectivity, PtM3/CeO2 shows a higher p-CAN selectivity (84.2–89.9 %) and significantly lower AN selectivity (0.4–0.8 %) compared to Pt/CeO2, indicating a positive effect of the second metal in inhibiting the dechlorination side reaction. However, when compared to γ-Al2O3 supported bi- and tri-metallic Pt-based catalysts as mentioned above, PtM3/CeO2 tends to produce a larger amount of intermediates. In order to investigate whether these intermediates can be converted to p-CAN and further to AN, the hydrogenation reaction time is prolonged after achieving complete conversion of p-CNB (Fig. S12). As presented in Table 2, the p-CAN selectivity on PtM3/CeO2 increases to above 95 % after the prolonged reaction time, while a very slight increase (0.1–0.2 %) in AN selectivity is observed. This demonstrates that the intermediates are effectively converted to p-CAN, and the dechlorination reaction remains suppressed on PtM3/CeO2. In contrast, Pt/CeO2 exhibits a decreased p-CAN selectivity from 83.0 % to 66.1 % and an increased AN selectivity from 6.9 % to 19.0 % after extending the reaction, indicating the occurrence of a severe dechlorination reaction. The outstanding dechlorination inhibition ability of PtM3/CeO2 can be attributed to the electron-deficient state of Pt, which weakens the reactivity of the C-Cl bond, similar to the aforementioned PtCu/γ-Al2O3. Bimetallic PtM/γ-Al2O3 (except PtCu/γ-Al2O3) generally displays an increased AN selectivity over prolonged reaction time (Fig. S4), e.g., from 5.3 % to 11.2 % on PtCo/γ-Al2O3, from 3.4 % to 5.5 % on PtNi/γ-Al2O3, and from 3.6 % to 10.3 % on PtSn/γ-Al2O3. This phenomenon is also observed with PtNi3/γ-Al2O3, which shares the same active metal composition as PtNi3/CeO2 but employs a different support. After a 25-min reaction on PtNi3/γ-Al2O3, the p-CNB conversion reaches 99.9 %, with p-CAN selectivity at 95.8 % and AN selectivity at 2.7 % (Fig. S6); upon extending the reaction time to 80 min, the p-CAN selectivity remains constant, but the AN selectivity increases to 3.5 %. This rise in AN selectivity greatly exceeds that observed on PtM3/CeO2, highlighting the superior ability of PtM3/CeO2 in suppressing the dechlorination reaction. Nevertheless, it is important to note that the trimetallic PtCuCox/γ-Al2O3 catalysts also have an excellent capability to inhibit the dechlorination even after extended reaction time (Fig. 6). As a result, it is difficulty to definitely determine which catalyst, PtM3/CeO2 or PtCuCox/γ-Al2O3, is better in this regard. However, it can be concluded that for CeO2-supported catalysts, bimetallic Pt-based catalysts can effectively inhibit the dechlorination side reaction, while for γ-Al2O3-supported catalysts, trimetallic Pt-based catalysts possess this ability. Among all the catalysts tested in this study, PtCuCo/γ-Al2O3 and PtNi3/CeO2 have displayed exceptional performance in both p-CNB hydrogenation and dechlorination inhibition, making them promising catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of p-CNB to p-CAN. 4 Conclusions A series of bimetallic PtM/γ-Al2O3 (M = Co, Cu, Ni, Fe, Zn, Ga and Sn) catalysts were synthesized by co-impregnation and evaluated for the selective hydrogenation of p-CNB. Among these catalysts, PtCo/γ-Al2O3 exhibited the highest hydrogenation activity, achieving a remarkable reaction rate of 318.22 μmol/(g·s), which could be attributed to the notably high electron-rich degree of Pt on the catalyst. On the other hand, PtCu/γ-Al2O3 showed the highest p-CAN selectivity (95.4 %) and the lowest AN selectivity (0.1 %). This selectivity was closely associated with the electron-deficient state of Pt, weakening the reactivity of the C-Cl bond and effectively inhibiting the dechlorination of p-CAN. However, the reaction rate on PtCu/γ-Al2O3 was comparatively lower at 19.06 μmol/(g·s). To further enhance the catalytic performance, we investigated PtCuCox/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with varying Co/Pt molar ratios. Impressively, PtCuCo/γ-Al2O3 displayed excellent hydrogenation performance with a reaction rate of 59.74 μmol/(g·s), p-CAN selectivity of 97.3 %, AN selectivity of 0.4 %, and good stability over a five-cycle test. The presence of Pt, Cu and Co metals synergistically contributed to the elevated p-CAN selectivity and improved hydrogenation activity compared to PtCu/γ-Al2O3. Moreover, we explored the selective hydrogenation of p-CNB on bimetallic PtM3/CeO2 (M = Co, Cu, Ni and Zn) catalysts. The AN selectivity on all PtM3/CeO2 catalysts was consistently less than 1 %, indicating that the dechlorination side reaction was effectively inhibited. Unlike the direct path from p-CNB to p-CAN predominantly occurring when γ-Al2O3 was used as the support, the use of CeO2 promoted the condensation path from p-CNB to p-CAN. Even extending the reaction time after achieving complete conversion of p-CNB, the AN selectively remained almost unchanged, while the p-CAN selectivity increased due to the conversion of intermediates. These findings demonstrate the significance of employing a multi-metal synergistic strategy and underscores the influential role of the catalyst support in the hydrogenation of chlorinated nitrobenzenes, providing valuable insights for future research in this field. coredata.dc:description: The selective hydrogenation of p-chloronitrobenzene (p-CNB) is a crucial step in the preparation of p-chloroaniline (p-CAN). However, the competitive reactions of NO2 hydrogenation and C-Cl hydrogenolysis make it challenging to inhibit the undesired dechlorination side reaction during this process. Herein, we developed a series of bimetallic PtM/γ-Al2O3 (M = Co, Cu, Ni, Fe, Zn, Ga, and Sn) and trimetallic PtCuCox/γ-Al2O3 catalysts to enhance the selectivity of p-CAN and suppress the formation of aniline (AN). Among the bimetallic catalysts, PtCo/γ-Al2O3 showed the highest hydrogenation activity due to its high electron-rich degree of Pt. Conversely, PtCu/γ-Al2O3 displayed the highest p-CAN selectivity and the lowest AN selectivity, primarily owing to the presence of electron-deficient Pt. Remarkably, the trimetallic PtCuCo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited superior hydrogenation performance, achieving 97.3 % p-CAN selectivity and 0.4 % AN selectivity at complete conversion of p-CNB, while maintaining good stability over five cycles. This enhancement was attributed to the synergistic effect among Pt, Cu and Co. To further investigate the effect of support, we prepared bimetallic PtM3 (M = Co, Cu, Ni and Zn) catalysts supported on reducible CeO2. Interestingly, the use of CeO2 as a support facilitated the condensation path from p-CNB to p-CAN via azobenzene compounds, distinct from the direct path observed with γ-Al2O3 support. Furthermore, the AN selectivity on all PtM3/CeO2 was less than 1 %, indicating effective inhibition of dechlorination reactions. This study highlights the importance of a multi-metal synergistic strategy and the effect of the support to achieve superior performance in chloronitrobenzene hydrogenation.
coredata.dc:title: Bimetallic and trimetallic Pt-based catalysts for selective hydrogenation of p-chloronitrobenzene to p-chloroaniline
